title: 108_hr1119
content:
The "Family Time Flexibility Act" allows compensatory time for employees. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow private employees to receive compensatory time off in lieu of monetary overtime compensation, at a rate of one and a half hours for each hour of overtime worked. This provision does not apply to employees of public agencies. Private employees can receive compensatory time off instead of monetary overtime compensation under a collective bargaining agreement or an agreement between the employer and employee before work. Private employees can choose to receive compensatory time off instead of monetary overtime compensation under specific conditions. The agreement must be voluntary and not a condition of employment. Employees must have worked at least 1000 hours in a 12-month period before being eligible for compensatory time off. The maximum limit for accruing compensatory time is 160 hours. Private employees can opt for compensatory time off instead of monetary overtime compensation under specific conditions. The employer must provide monetary compensation for any unused compensatory time off accrued during the previous calendar year by January 31 of each year. The maximum limit for accruing compensatory time is 160 hours. Employees can receive monetary compensation for unused compensatory time exceeding 80 hours with 30 days notice. Employers can discontinue compensatory time policies with 30 days notice, unless specified in a collective bargaining agreement. Employees can withdraw agreements for compensatory time and request monetary compensation for unused time in writing. Within 30 days of a written request, the employer must provide monetary compensation to the employee as per paragraph (6). Employers cannot intimidate or coerce employees who request compensatory time off instead of monetary overtime compensation. Employees can withdraw agreements for compensatory time and request monetary compensation for unused time. Upon termination of employment, employees with accrued compensatory time off must be paid for the unused time at a rate not less than their regular or final rate of compensation. Employees must be paid for any unused compensatory time at their regular or final rate of compensation upon termination. Compensatory time off must be granted within a reasonable period after a request, as long as it does not disrupt the employer's operations. Overtime compensation and compensatory time are defined in subsection (o)(7). SEC. 3. REMEDIES.

Amends the Fair Labor Standards Act to hold employers liable for compensatory time violations. An employer violating section 7(r)(4) must compensate affected employees for accrued and used compensatory time. Liquidated damages are also imposed.

SEC. 4. NOTICE TO EMPLOYEES. The Secretary of Labor must update materials provided to employers within 30 days to reflect amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act. The Act and its amendments will expire 5 years after enactment.
